try a package-centric approach

  The idea is for package writers to develop their packages as if they were pure
  python, except with the addition of C/C++ source files scattered where
  desired.  The mapping of source files to libraries are provided by
  CMakeList.txt files, which must install the libraries within the source
  directory; at the locations where the imports in the pure python portions of
  the package expect them.

  This example follows popular practice for packages featuring a mix of pure and
  compiled code.  Most compiled functionality are isolated in self-contained
  modules that are built into shared libraries with names starting with an
  underscore (_).  These libraries are paired with a pure python module of the
  same name sans underscore.  In this module the compiled functionality is
  exposed with the desired wrappings, or more commonly, a direct pass-through
  import (from ._compiled import *).

  - Also improves cmake integration by directly passing PYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR and
    PYTHON_LIBRARY variables.
    - prioritizes dynamic over static libraries

                not self.has_c_libraries())
    [...]

avoid escaping spaces (#265)

spaces in CYTHON_FLAGS are incorrectly escaped (at least on linux) when provided as command line arguments to the cython executable through CMake cache entries.

Here is a simple mwe (run `$ bash build.sh` in a terminal)
**build.sh**
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
rm -r build; mkdir -p build; cd build

cmake \
-DCYTHON_FLAGS='-X boundscheck=False -X wraparound=False' \
-DCMAKE_MODULE_PATH="$SKBUILD_PREFIX/skbuild/resources/cmake" \
-DCMAKE_VERBOSE_MAKEFILE=ON ..

make || exit 1

python3 -c 'import fib; fib.fib(2000)'
```
**CMakeLists.txt**
```CMake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.8)

project(fib)

find_package(Cython REQUIRED)
include(UseCython)

include_directories(${PYTHON_INCLUDE_DIRS})

add_cython_target(fib fib.pyx C PY3)
add_library(fib MODULE fib.c)
set_target_properties(fib PROPERTIES PREFIX "")
```

**fib.pyx**
```python
def fib(n):
    """Print the Fibonacci series up to n."""
    a, b = 0, 1
    while b < n:
        print(b)
        a, b = b, a + b
```

without this patch, build.sh fails with the following output
```bash
<...>
cython --include-dir <...>/include/python3.6m -3 -X\ boundscheck=False\ -X\ wraparound=False <...>/fib.pyx --output-file <...>/build/fib.c
Error in compiler directive: boundscheck directive must be set to True or False, got 'False -X wraparound=False'
<...>
make[2]: *** [CMakeFiles/fib.dir/build.make:65: fib.c] Error 1
make[2]: Leaving directory <...>/build'
```

FindPythonExtensions: Do not override cpp symbols when using gcc on Linux

This partially reverts f6ea5d0af (FindPythonExtensions: Set symbol visibility
to export only module init function) to ensure all local symbols are externally
visible.

symbols other than the CPython module entrypoint (PyInit_<moduleName>
or init<moduleName>).

Since selectively listing additional symbols is not scalable (see [1]), this
commit ensures all symbols are visible.

fix: validate value before returning library path (#942)

* fix: validate value before returning library path

In CMaker._guess_python_library(), there is a path where python_library
can be set to a file name without a path. For example, this happens
when using a venv in a MinGW envronment on Windows. This gets passed
to CMake via Python_LIBRARY which causes CMake to fail.

To fix it, we validate that the path exists on disk before returning
the value or return None if it does not exist.

Fixes: https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/issues/940
